wikipedia_page.main: Charles Wallace Alexander Napier Cochrane-Baillie, 2nd Baron Lamington,  (29 July 1860 – 16 September 1940) was a British politician and colonial administrator who served as Governor of Queensland from 1896 to 1901, and Governor of Bombay from 1903 to 1907.

response: *1860 – Charles Cochrane-Baillie, 2nd Baron Lamington, English politician, 8th Governor of Queensland (d. 1940)
*1940 – Charles Cochrane-Baillie, 2nd Baron Lamington, English-Scottish politician, 8th Governor of Queensland (b. 1860)

link_mentions.page: List of people on the postage stamps of Australia
response: * Charles Cochrane-Baillie, 2nd Baron Lamington, as Governor of Queensland and Lady Lamington (2009) with the eponymous dessert

link_mentions.page: List of foods named after people
response: * Lamingtons – these small cakes, considered one of Australia's national foods, are usually considered to be named after Charles Cochrane-Baillie, 2nd Baron Lamington, who was governor of Queensland 1896–1901. There are other interesting claims.lamingtons
*Charles Cochrane-Baillie, 2nd Baron Lamington (1860–1940), Governor of Queensland (1896–1901)
The mountain was named after Charles Cochrane-Baillie, 2nd Baron Lamington who was Governor of Queensland.

On 13 March 1940, Michael O'Dwyer was scheduled to speak at a joint meeting of the East India Association and the Central Asian Society (now Royal Society for Asian Affairs) at Caxton Hall, London. Singh concealed a revolver inside a book, which had pages cut in the shape of a revolver. This revolver was purchased by him from a soldier in a pub.The Murders of the Black Museum: 1870–1970  p. 365 Then he entered the hall and found an open seat. As the meeting concluded, Singh shot O'Dwyer twice as he moved towards the speaking platform. One of these bullets passed through O'Dwyer's heart and right lung, killing him almost instantly. Others injured in the shooting included Sir Louis Dane, Lawrence Dundas, 2nd Marquess of Zetland,Glasgow Herald 19 March 1940 and Charles Cochrane-Baillie, 2nd Baron Lamington. Singh was arrested immediately after the shooting.The Black Museum  pp. 364–365
*Governor of Queensland – Charles Cochrane-Baillie, 2nd Baron Lamington (from 9 April)
